alt_statements.statement: As someone who believes in fairness, civic engagement, and teaching young people that every voice matters equally, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote for president. The current system can effectively discount millions of ballots in “safe” states and pushes campaigns to focus on a handful of swing states, which sends the wrong message to our students about democratic participation. A straightforward popular vote would more accurately reflect the will of the people and align better with the values of equality and representation that we try to model in our schools and our community.

As a high school English teacher and a lifelong North Carolinian, I believe we should move toward a national popular vote for president so that every citizen’s ballot carries equal weight, no matter where they live. The Electoral College feels increasingly outdated and distorts candidates’ attention toward a handful of swing states, rather than encouraging them to engage with the whole country. At the very least, states should adopt proportional allocation of electors or the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to better reflect the will of the people while we work toward a fairer, more democratic system.

At my age, I’ve seen a lot of elections come and go, and I still think the Electoral College plays an important role in making sure smaller states and more rural areas like many where I’ve worked aren’t steamrolled by the big coastal cities. That said, I’d be open to modest reforms—like allocating electoral votes by congressional district or tightening rules around faithless electors—so the system stays fair and accountable without tossing out the safeguards the Founders put in place.

As a Democrat and someone who really believes in fairness and health—of people and of our democracy—I think the Electoral College needs to be replaced with a national popular vote. Every vote should count equally, no matter what state you live in, just like everyone’s entitled to the same basic rights and opportunities. A popular vote would push candidates to actually speak to the issues that matter to people everywhere, not just to a handful of swing states.

As a Democrat who cares a lot about fairness and representation, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether you’re in Delaware or a swing state. It doesn’t sit right with me that someone can win the presidency while losing the popular vote, and it feels like my voice is discounted just because of where I live. A direct popular vote would push candidates to campaign everywhere and speak to the whole country, not just a handful of states.

Given my work in the nonprofit sector and my belief in civic equity, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot carries the same weight, regardless of state lines. The current system distorts campaign priorities toward a handful of swing states and weakens the sense that each individual’s vote truly matters. A well-designed national popular vote, paired with strong voting rights protections and standardized election administration, would better reflect our democratic values and the will of the people.

Given how much time I spend examining fine print and weighing evidence, the Electoral College just looks like an outdated mechanism that distorts the actual will of voters and over-privileges a handful of swing states. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, or at minimum reforms like ranked-choice voting and proportional allocation of electors so that every ballot—whether it’s cast in New Mexico or New York—has the same weight in choosing the president.

As someone who spends her days immersed in data and evidence, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, or at least significantly reformed to better reflect the principle of “one person, one vote.” The current system effectively magnifies the voices of a few swing states while muting millions of voters elsewhere, which offends both my scientific sense of fairness and my belief in equal representation. A nationwide popular vote—with robust safeguards like automatic voter registration, secure paper trails, and nonpartisan administration—would align our electoral system more closely with how we evaluate outcomes in research: every data point (or voter) counted once, transparently and directly.

As a retired artist and lifelong Californian, I’ve always believed that every person’s voice should count equally, and our presidential elections should reflect that. I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote, or at least substantially reformed so that votes in big blue states like mine aren’t effectively taken for granted while smaller swing states get all the attention. To me, a more direct and democratic system would better honor the dignity and equality of each voter, which fits both my liberal values and my Catholic belief in the fundamental worth of every person.

As someone who’s spent a career in finance, I’m acutely aware of how distortions in a system can skew outcomes, and the Electoral College is a prime example: it gives outsized power to a handful of swing states and undermines the basic democratic principle of one person, one vote. I’d like to see it replaced with a national popular vote, possibly with ranked-choice voting, so every ballot is weighed equally and candidates have to appeal to the whole country, not just a narrow slice of it.

Given how much emphasis we put on fairness and representation in civics class, the Electoral College feels outdated and undemocratic to me. I think we should move to a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts equally, whether they live in Connecticut or a swing state, and so candidates have to care about all communities, including racially diverse and younger voters like me. If a full popular vote isn’t possible right away, at least states should adopt a proportional system so the outcome better reflects the actual will of the people.

I think the Electoral College needs serious reform, if not full replacement, because every vote should count the same no matter what state you live in. A national popular vote would make candidates pay attention to people like me and my community, instead of just a few swing states. At the very least, states should move to proportional allocation of electors so the outcome better reflects the will of the people.

At my age, I’ve seen the country go through a lot, and I still believe the Electoral College plays an important role in protecting smaller states and preventing big cities from completely deciding our elections. I don’t think it should be abolished, but it could be improved by tightening rules so that states can’t just change how they allocate electors for partisan advantage. The Constitution’s structure has served us well for a long time, and any reform should respect that design instead of chasing every political trend.

As someone who swore an oath to uphold the Constitution, I respect the history behind the Electoral College, but I think it’s out of step with modern democracy. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote or at least reforms like proportional allocation of electors so that every vote, whether it’s in Massachusetts or a swing state, counts equally. That would make the system fairer, increase turnout, and reduce the feeling that a handful of states decide the presidency for everyone else.

My parents and older siblings tell me that voting for president should feel fair to everyone, no matter what state they live in. I think we should count every person’s vote the same across the whole country, so whoever most people pick becomes president. That sounds more like when we all vote in my family on what game to play or what show to watch, and the choice with the most “yes” wins.

As someone who worked hard to build a life here and chose this country, I’d like to see the Electoral College reformed toward a fairer reflection of the popular will without completely ignoring smaller states. A system that allocates electoral votes proportionally by state, or uses ranked-choice voting within states, would still respect the federal structure but make every vote feel like it truly counts.

As someone who guides students from all over the country and sees how different communities feel politically sidelined, I think we should replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote. Every ballot should count the same, whether you live in a swing state or not, so candidates have to pay attention to all voters, not just a handful of states. A ranked-choice national popular vote could also help make sure the winner actually reflects the broadest support, not just a narrow partisan base.

As a naturalized citizen who teaches civics to kids, I find it harder and harder to justify an Electoral College system that can ignore the national popular vote and make some Americans’ voices matter more just because of where they live. I support replacing the Electoral College with a direct popular vote—possibly with ranked-choice voting—so every ballot is equal and candidates have to speak to the whole country, not just a handful of swing states.

As someone who values both tradition and fairness, I believe we should keep the Electoral College but make modest reforms to improve representation and trust. I would support changes like allocating electoral votes by congressional district or requiring states to follow clearer, uniform rules for elections and recounts, so every lawful vote is respected while still preserving the balance between large and small states that our founders intended.

At my age, having taught American history for decades, I’ve come to see the Electoral College as an outdated compromise that often undermines the principle of one person, one vote. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, or at least reforming it so that electoral votes are awarded proportionally within each state, to better reflect the will of the people. From a democratic and Catholic social teaching perspective—emphasizing human dignity and the common good—it troubles me that some citizens’ votes effectively count more than others simply because of where they live.

As a civics-minded teacher and a Democrat, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, no matter what state a person lives in. Our students learn that democracy is about “one person, one vote,” but the current system distorts that principle and encourages candidates to focus on a handful of swing states. A well-designed popular vote system—with national standards for ballot access and election security—would better reflect the will of the people and align more honestly with the democratic and ethical values I try to teach in my classroom.

Given how much I care about community and making sure everyone has a real voice, I think we should replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system makes a few swing states way too powerful and can put someone in the White House who didn’t actually win the most votes, which doesn’t feel democratic or fair. As a Democrat and a liberal, I want reforms that expand participation and representation, not ones that distort it.

I think the Electoral College needs some updating, but I’m not sold on scrapping it entirely. A system where states award their electoral votes proportionally, or follow the popular vote within each congressional district, might keep smaller and rural states like mine from getting steamrolled while still making every vote feel like it counts. What I don’t want is a setup where only big cities and coastal states decide everything, but I do think people should feel their individual vote matters more than it does now.

The Electoral College feels outdated and undemocratic to me—every vote should count the same, no matter what state you live in. I’d like to see us move to a national popular vote, or at least require states to allocate their electors proportionally so candidates have to pay attention to more than just a handful of swing states. As a working mom trying to raise kids to believe in fairness and responsibility, it’s hard to defend a system where the person with fewer votes can still win the presidency.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but maybe updated a bit so people feel their vote counts more, like using the district-based system they have in Maine and Nebraska. The current system helps make sure smaller, rural states like West Virginia still have a voice and aren’t totally steamrolled by big cities.

I think the person who gets the most votes from everybody in the whole country should be the president, because that feels the most fair, like when we vote in class and we count everyone’s vote the same. The Electoral College seems confusing, and it feels weird that someone could lose the popular vote but still win, so I’d want to change it so every person’s vote counts equally no matter what state they live in.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but it could use some fine-tuning rather than a full overhaul. It forces candidates to build broader coalitions across states instead of just chasing votes in the biggest cities, which helps protect smaller and rural states like mine from being ignored. If anything, I’d support reforms to make the process more transparent and ensure that states follow clear, consistent rules, but not a switch to a straight national popular vote.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but with some careful improvements rather than throwing it out entirely. It helps make sure smaller and more rural states like mine aren’t totally drowned out by big cities, but I’d be open to reforms like tightening up how electors are chosen or encouraging states to use a fairer system for awarding their votes. I don’t want a straight popular vote where a few large states decide everything, but I do think we should make the process more transparent and trustworthy so people have more confidence in the results.

As a Democrat and a believer in one-person-one-vote, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every American’s ballot counts equally, whether you live in Ohio like me or in a so‑called “swing state.” It doesn’t make sense that a candidate can win the popular vote and still lose the presidency, and that system leaves a lot of people feeling ignored and stressed about whether their voice matters. A direct popular vote would push candidates to focus on the health, jobs, and everyday concerns of all Americans, not just a handful of battleground states.

As a young dad and a Democrat, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts the same, whether you’re in a swing state or not. Coming from a working-class background, it doesn’t sit right with me that someone can win the presidency while losing the popular vote, because it makes regular people feel like our voices don’t matter as much. If fully replacing it isn’t politically realistic, I’d support reforms like proportional allocation of electoral votes or the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to make the system more democratic and fair.

I don’t support scrapping the Electoral College, because it forces candidates to build coalitions across states instead of just pandering to big cities and the coasts. That said, I’d be open to reforms like allocating electors by congressional district, with a few going to the statewide winner, so rural and smaller communities like the ones I’ve served don’t get drowned out, but individual votes still feel like they matter more.

As a conservative and a firm believer in our constitutional framework, I think the Electoral College should be preserved, not scrapped. It forces candidates to build broad, geographically diverse support rather than just pandering to a few big cities. That said, I’d support modest, state-led reforms—like better transparency around how electors are chosen—rather than any sweeping federal overhaul or move to a national popular vote.

As someone who believes in fairness and careful organization, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot carries equal weight, no matter where a person lives. As a naturalized citizen, I take my vote very seriously, and it troubles me that a candidate can win the presidency without winning the most votes. At the same time, I would support reforms like ranked-choice voting nationwide to encourage more respectful, issue-focused campaigns and reduce polarization.

As someone who believes in broad democratic participation and has seen how diverse and creative communities can be overlooked, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote. Every vote should carry equal weight regardless of where you live, so candidates have to engage with people across the entire country, not just a handful of swing states. If a full replacement isn’t politically feasible right away, I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact as a major step toward a fairer, more representative system.

Como inmigrante que no puede votar, pero que ve cuánto afectan las decisiones del gobierno a las familias como la mía, siento que el sistema del Colegio Electoral no siempre refleja verdaderamente la voluntad de la gente. Me gustaría que el presidente se eligiera por voto popular directo, donde cada voto cuente igual sin importar el estado, para que las comunidades de inmigrantes y las personas sin poder político ni dinero tengan más peso. Un sistema más sencillo y justo también podría reducir la desconfianza y animar a más personas a involucrarse, incluso si, como yo, todavía no tienen ciudadanía.

As an Independent who tries to look at issues from a practical, fair-minded angle, I think the Electoral College should be reformed but not completely abolished. I’d like to see states move toward something like proportional allocation of electoral votes or ranked-choice voting within the current framework, so that every vote feels more meaningful and candidates have to appeal beyond a few swing states. That seems like a reasonable balance between respecting the structure our founders set up and making sure people in all parts of the country, including families like mine, feel their voices count.

I think the Electoral College is outdated and we ought to move to a straightforward national popular vote, where every ballot counts the same no matter what state you’re in. As someone who works hard, pays a lot in taxes, and doesn’t feel tied to either party, I’m tired of seeing a handful of “swing states” get all the attention while the rest of us are basically background noise. A simple popular vote would make candidates actually compete for every voter instead of gaming the map, and that lines up better with the idea of individual liberty and equal representation.

At my age, having spent a lifetime inside courtrooms and watching our institutions up close, I find the Electoral College increasingly difficult to justify under any consistent theory of equal protection. I would support a national popular vote—ideally implemented through a constitutional amendment—so that every ballot is weighted equally, regardless of state lines. Short of that, reforms such as proportional allocation of electors or ranked-choice voting layered onto the presidential contest would at least mitigate the current system’s distortion of voter power and its tendency to sideline millions of voices.

The Electoral College is sketchy because it lets a handful of states decide everything while everyone else just gets background-noise status. If we’re gonna pretend this is a democracy at all, it should be straight-up popular vote so every ballot counts the same, whether you’re in some swing state or not. Honestly, I don’t trust any system that keeps power locked up at the top, so getting rid of the Electoral College is at least one step toward people actually having a say instead of being played.

As someone who grew up watching games decided by clear scores, I think our elections should work more like the scoreboard: the candidate with the most votes nationwide should win. I’d support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote or at least reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, so every vote in every state counts the same. That feels fairer, easier to explain, and more in line with how we judge performance in every other competitive arena.

I don’t see any need to scrap the Electoral College, though I’d consider some modest reforms. It forces candidates to build broad, nationwide support instead of just pandering to big cities on the coasts, and that balance has served the country well. If anything, we might look at tightening rules around how electors are chosen and making the process more transparent, but the basic system should stay in place.

I think the Electoral College is kind of confusing and doesn’t seem fair, because sometimes the person with the most votes from the people doesn’t become president. I’d rather have a system where every vote counts the same no matter what state you live in, so a popular vote sounds better to me. That way, kids like me growing up in places like Nebraska would know that when we’re old enough, our vote matters just as much as anyone else’s.

Como alguien que no es ciudadana y que viene de México, a veces me cuesta entender por qué el presidente no se elige simplemente por el voto popular, como estoy acostumbrada a pensar. El Colegio Electoral se siente lejano y complicado, y parece que le da más importancia a ciertos estados que a otros. Yo preferiría un sistema donde cada voto cuente igual sin importar en qué estado viva la persona, porque eso me parece más justo y más fácil de confiar.

The Electoral College is outdated and should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every vote counts equally, no matter whether you live in Indiana or California. As someone who believes in fairness and accountability, I don’t like the idea of a candidate winning the presidency while losing the popular vote. With today’s technology, we can securely count every vote nationwide, and the person with the most votes should simply win. If a full replacement isn’t possible right away, I’d support reforms like proportional allocation of electors to better reflect the will of the people.

At my age, I’ve come to see the value of stability in our institutions, and I believe the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in protecting the voice of smaller states and rural communities like the one I grew up in. I would support modest reforms—such as greater transparency, or encouraging states to allocate electors by congressional district rather than winner-take-all—but I do not think we should abandon the Electoral College for a pure popular vote.

As a conservative and a Christian, I believe the Electoral College is an important safeguard that protects the voice of smaller states like New Mexico and keeps our elections from being dominated by a few big coastal cities. I’m open to modest reforms that improve transparency and discourage attempts to manipulate the system, but I oppose getting rid of the Electoral College or moving to a pure national popular vote, which I think would further divide the country and weaken our federal system.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because it feels more fair that every single person’s vote counts the same no matter what state they live in. Growing up in California, it sometimes feels like our votes are already decided, and that makes people my age less interested in politics. If we really care about democracy and everyone having a voice—like we say we do in school and at church—then the system should match that by directly reflecting what most voters want.

I think the Electoral College should be reformed so that every person’s vote counts more equally, maybe through a national popular vote or at least by having states split their electoral votes by district or proportion. As a Democrat and a Catholic who believes in fairness and responsibility, it bothers me that a few swing states end up deciding everything while millions of votes in other places feel like they don’t matter. I want a system where candidates have to speak to people all over the country, including communities like mine, not just chase battleground states.

I support keeping the Electoral College, but I’d be open to some reforms that keep its basic structure while making it work better. It forces candidates to pay attention to more than just big cities and protects smaller and rural states, which I think is important for a country as large and diverse as ours. If anything, I’d favor changes that increase transparency and make sure every legal vote is counted accurately within each state, rather than moving to a straight national popular vote that could sideline people in places like my community.

The Electoral College is an anachronism that undermines the democratic principle of “one person, one vote,” and it should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot carries equal weight, regardless of state lines. Short of a full constitutional amendment, I would support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact and eliminating winner-take-all allocations to reduce distortions and ensure outcomes more faithfully reflect the will of the people.

The Electoral College is a core part of the constitutional system, and I don’t support scrapping it in favor of a pure popular vote that would let a handful of big cities decide every election. That said, I’d be open to modest reforms that keep the state-based structure—like tightening rules around faithless electors or improving how states allocate their electoral votes—so the process is more transparent and people trust the outcome.

As someone who really believes in equality and community voice, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts the same, no matter what state they live in. At the very least, we should move to a proportional system in each state instead of winner-take-all, so the outcome better reflects the actual choices of voters.

At my age, having taught young people to think critically about democracy, I’ve come to believe the Electoral College is outdated and should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot carries equal weight, no matter the state. Watching elections where the winner of the popular vote loses the presidency has been disheartening and, frankly, undermines faith in the system. A direct popular vote, with safeguards for voting rights and access, would better reflect the will of the people and align with the democratic ideals I spent my career teaching.

As someone who loves this country and became a citizen later in life, I respect the Constitution and think the Electoral College has helped keep a balance between big states and small states. However, I do believe some reforms could make it fairer, like requiring states to divide their electoral votes more proportionally instead of winner-take-all, so more voices are heard. I would not support getting rid of the Electoral College completely, but I’m open to changes that keep our system stable while making sure every vote feels like it matters.

Given how deeply unequal political power has been in this country—especially for Black communities—I’m uncomfortable with a system where a few swing states and an outdated compromise can override the national popular will. I’d support replacing the Electoral College with a straightforward popular vote, ideally with ranked-choice voting so people can vote their conscience without “wasting” their vote. That feels more humane and democratic, giving every person’s ballot the same weight regardless of where they live.

I don’t totally understand all the details, but it seems fair to me that every person’s vote should count the same no matter what state they live in. Maybe we should change the Electoral College so that the popular vote picks the president, or at least make the system closer to that. That way, everyone, even kids like me when we grow up, would feel like our vote really matters equally.

I don’t totally get all the complicated parts of the Electoral College, but it seems kind of unfair that someone can win the most votes in the whole country and still lose the election. I think it would be better if every person’s vote counted the same no matter what state they live in, so the winner is whoever gets the most votes from all the people. Maybe grown-ups could change the rules so smaller states still get heard, but not in a way that makes people feel like their vote doesn’t really matter.

Given my background as a scientist and an immigrant who cannot yet vote, I find the Electoral College deeply out of step with both empirical evidence and democratic principles. I would favor replacing it with a national popular vote, ideally through the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, so that every ballot is weighed equally regardless of state lines. This would reduce the disproportionate influence of swing states, encourage broader voter participation, and better reflect the will of a diverse electorate.

At my age, I’ve seen enough elections to feel that the Electoral College just doesn’t reflect the will of the people the way it should. I’d like to see us move toward a national popular vote, or at least a system like ranked-choice voting that makes every ballot count the same, whether you’re in Georgia or Wyoming. As a Democrat and a Christian, I believe in fairness and the dignity of every person’s voice, and our system ought to mirror that as closely as possible.

As someone who cares deeply about social justice and making sure every community has a real voice, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts equally, regardless of state. The current system makes some votes feel more important than others and can ignore the voices of communities like mine—immigrants, people of color, and working families. A popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and strengthen our democracy by encouraging candidates to listen to all Americans, not just those in a handful of swing states.

As a mom and a voter, I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts equally, no matter what state they live in. It doesn’t feel right that a handful of swing states get most of the attention while families like mine, just trying to get by and be heard, can be effectively sidelined. A popular vote system would push candidates to speak to everyone—rural, urban, and in-between—on issues like health care, wages, and education, instead of just chasing the same few states every four years.

The Electoral College is an outdated system that distorts the principle of “one person, one vote” and encourages campaigns to focus narrowly on a handful of swing states. I’d favor a national popular vote for president, paired with robust federal standards for voting access and election security, so every ballot is weighed equally regardless of where you live. If a full constitutional amendment proves impossible, I’d support interstate compacts and proportional allocation of electors as interim steps that move us closer to genuine majority rule.

I don’t like the idea of a handful of swing states deciding things for the whole country, but I’m also wary of any plan that just hands everything over to the biggest cities and ignores smaller, rural places like where I’m from. I’d support reforms that keep the Electoral College but make states split their electoral votes by district or proportionally, so people’s votes feel like they count more no matter where they live. That way we protect the voice of smaller communities and individual liberty without letting the system stay as skewed and winner-take-all as it is now.

I think the Electoral College should be preserved but updated, not scrapped. As a conservative and a legal immigrant, I value the way it forces candidates to pay attention to different states instead of just big cities, but I’d support reforms like allocating electors by congressional district or tightening state-level rules to prevent last-minute changes and confusion.

My mommy says the president should be the person that the most people pick, like when we all vote on which game to play at preschool. I think it should be more fair so every person’s vote counts the same, even where my family lives and on the reservation too. Maybe they can change the rules so it’s just everyone’s votes all together, and whoever gets the most wins.

I don’t totally get all the details about the Electoral College, but it seems kind of weird that the person with the most votes in the whole country doesn’t always become president. I think it would be more fair if everyone’s vote counted the same, no matter what state they live in, kind of like how our student council votes work at school. Maybe grown-ups could change it so the winner is just whoever gets the most votes from all the people.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but maybe updated a little. It protects smaller states like Missouri from being totally ignored by big cities, and that seems fair and in line with how our country was set up. If anything changed, I’d rather see reforms that make sure states run their elections more securely and consistently, instead of getting rid of the Electoral College altogether.

As someone who travels and performs across the country, I’m constantly reminded that every voice deserves the same weight, whether it’s in New York or a small town in the Midwest. I’d support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote, or at least adopting reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, so the presidency truly reflects the will of the majority. A system where some states are “battlegrounds” and others are background noise doesn’t reflect the democratic, expressive spirit I believe art—and our politics—should embody.

As someone who believes every person’s vote should count the same, I think we should move to a national popular vote for president and get rid of the Electoral College. It doesn’t feel right that a few swing states get all the attention while people like me in Kansas might as well be invisible. A popular vote would push candidates to care about all communities, including Black voters and folks with disabilities in smaller or more rural states.

At my age, I’ve lived through enough elections to feel that every vote should count the same, no matter where you live, so I would support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote. The current system makes some states matter far more than others and can ignore the voices of people, like many in my own community, who faithfully vote but never see their state in play. A direct popular vote, with strong protections for voting rights and access, would better reflect our democratic values and give citizens a clearer sense that their participation truly matters.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because it feels unfair that some people’s votes matter more just because of the state they live in. In school we learn that everyone’s voice counts the same, so our elections should match that and pick the president based on who actually gets the most votes across the whole country.

I’ve never been entirely comfortable with the Electoral College, especially after seeing candidates win the presidency while losing the popular vote. I’d support a system where the national popular vote actually decides the winner, or at least reforms like proportional allocation of electors by state so people’s votes feel like they count more equally. That said, I do think smaller states deserve some protection, so any change should make sure they’re not completely drowned out by the big cities.

As someone who believes in fairness and democratic participation, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every individual’s ballot counts equally, no matter what state they live in. The current system makes a few swing states way too important and can ignore the voices of people in places like Kansas, where I’m from. A direct popular vote would push candidates to campaign everywhere, listen to more diverse communities, and better reflect the will of the people.

I think it’s past time we move to a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts the same, whether they’re in New York or some tiny swing state. As someone who’s lived a long life believing in individual responsibility and democratic values, it bothers me that a few states get all the attention while the rest of us are taken for granted. We should either abolish the Electoral College or at least reform it so electoral votes are awarded proportionally, not winner-take-all.

As someone who believes deeply in fairness and works every day in a diverse campus community, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot truly counts the same, whether it’s cast in Iowa or California. The current system makes many voters feel invisible and distorts candidates’ priorities toward a handful of swing states. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people, encourage broader participation, and align our presidential elections with the democratic values we teach our students.

I don’t really understand all the big parts of the Electoral College, but I think it would be fair if everyone’s vote counted the same, no matter what state they live in. Grown‑ups could change it so the person with the most votes from all the people in the country becomes president, kind of like how we vote for class helpers at school.

I think it’s past time we moved to a national popular vote so every ballot counts the same, whether you’re in a swing state or not. As a small business owner and a Black woman, I’m tired of seeing candidates chase after a handful of states while ignoring communities like mine that always show up to vote. We need a system where the person with the most votes actually wins, and where turnout in places like rural Virginia matters just as much as it does in Ohio or Florida.

I think we should keep the Electoral College, but update it so each state awards its electors by congressional district, like Maine and Nebraska do, with a few bonus electors going to the statewide winner. That way, folks in rural areas and smaller states like mine don’t get steamrolled by big cities, but individual votes still matter more. I don’t trust a straight popular vote where California and New York could basically decide everything, but I’m open to tweaks that make the system feel fairer and more representative.

As someone who believes in social equality and works hard every day to support my family, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts the same, no matter what state they live in. It doesn’t make sense that a president can win without getting the most votes from the people. A direct popular vote would make our democracy more fair and make politicians pay attention to all communities, including working-class and Latino families like mine, instead of just a few swing states.

At my age, having watched many elections come and go, I still believe the Electoral College serves an important purpose in protecting the voice of smaller states like my own. That said, I would support some careful reforms—such as allocating electoral votes by congressional district or improving how states handle recounts—to better reflect the will of the people without letting large urban areas completely dominate national elections.

My mom tells me that when people vote for president, sometimes the one with more people liking him still doesn’t win because of something called the Electoral College, and that feels a little unfair to me. I think it would be better if every person’s vote just counted the same no matter where they live, like when we all get one turn in a game and it really counts. Maybe grown-ups could change the rules so the person who gets the most votes from all the people in the whole country is the one who wins.

As someone who works in education and cares a lot about how we teach fairness and civics to kids, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every individual’s ballot counts equally, no matter what state they live in. The current system overemphasizes a handful of swing states and can result in presidents who didn’t win the most votes overall, which undermines trust in the democratic process. A direct popular vote would be simpler to explain, more transparent, and more consistent with the idea that all citizens’ voices carry the same weight.

I think the president should be chosen by whoever gets the most votes from people all over the country, because that feels the most fair, like when we vote for class reps at school. The Electoral College seems confusing and can make some people’s votes matter less just because of where they live, which doesn’t seem right. If we changed it so every vote counts the same, I think more people would trust the system and care about voting.

I don’t really get all the complicated stuff about the Electoral College, but it seems weird that the person with fewer votes can still be president. I think it would be more fair if everyone’s vote just counted the same no matter what state they live in, like when we vote for class president and whoever gets the most votes wins.

Given how polarized our politics have become, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot carries equal weight, whether you live in Illinois or a swing state. As someone who cares about the environment and supports the Green Party, it’s frustrating that third-party votes often feel meaningless under the current system, which concentrates power in a few battleground states. A direct popular vote—or at least reforms like ranked-choice voting combined with a national popular vote—would better reflect the real diversity of opinion in this country and encourage candidates to address long-term issues like climate and conservation, not just short-term partisan battles.

At my age, I’ve seen this country go through many changes, and I believe our Electoral College still serves an important purpose in protecting the voice of smaller and more rural states from being drowned out by big cities. I don’t support abolishing it, but I would be open to some modest reforms—like making sure states run their elections more uniformly and transparently—so people can trust the results. The Founders designed a system to slow down sudden swings in public opinion, and I think that stability has been good for America.

I don’t really understand all the details about the Electoral College, but I think everyone’s vote should count the same no matter where they live, kind of like how everyone on a team gets one turn. It feels fair if the person who the most people pick becomes the leader, like choosing a class helper by everyone raising their hands. That way, people in every place—big cities and small towns—know their voices matter.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved, but modernized around the idea of states’ rights and fair representation. Instead of abolishing it for a national popular vote, I’d support reforms like tightening election integrity measures in each state and possibly adopting a system where each congressional district awards an electoral vote, so that rural and smaller communities like the ones I grew up around in Georgia still have a real voice against big coastal cities.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that every individual vote counts the same, no matter what state you live in. As a young person in California who can’t vote yet, it worries me that some states get so much more attention than others, and it feels like people’s voices can be ignored. A national popular vote, or at least a system that awards electoral votes more fairly, would make elections feel more honest and encourage more people—especially young and Latino voters—to care and participate.

I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in making sure smaller states like Iowa have a real voice, instead of everything being decided by a few big coastal cities. That said, I’d be open to reforms that keep the state-by-state balance but make it fairer, like allocating electors by congressional district or tightening rules so states can’t just change the game for partisan advantage.

As someone who became a citizen by choice and runs a small shop that depends on every single customer, I believe every individual vote should count equally, no matter what state you live in. I would support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote so presidents are chosen by the people directly, instead of by a system that can ignore the majority. At the very least, we should reform it—like adopting the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact—so that our elections better reflect the will of all Americans, including immigrants like me who worked hard to have a voice.

I think the Electoral College still has an important role in protecting the voice of smaller states like Missouri, so I wouldn’t support scrapping it altogether. However, I’d be open to some sensible reforms—like allocating electors by congressional district or tightening rules around faithless electors—so that people feel their votes matter more without turning our elections into a chaotic national popular vote contest.

I think it’s past time we move to a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts equally, whether you live in Indiana or California. The Electoral College makes some votes matter more than others and encourages politicians to chase a handful of swing states instead of speaking to the whole country. A straightforward popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and push candidates to earn support everywhere, not just in the places that game the system.

I think it’s time to move to a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts the same, whether you’re in New York, Texas, or a small town anywhere else. The current Electoral College gives too much power to a few swing states and can ignore the will of the majority, which doesn’t sit right with my sense of fairness and democracy. As a Democrat and a Catholic who cares about everyone having a voice, I want a system where candidates have to speak to all communities—including Hispanic and working-class families like mine—not just the ones that tip the Electoral College.

At my age, I’ve come to respect the wisdom of the Founders, and I believe the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in protecting the voice of smaller states and preventing a few big cities from dominating national elections. That said, I would support modest reforms that increase transparency and ensure states run their elections cleanly and consistently, perhaps by standardizing some procedures. I’m wary of rushing into a national popular vote, which I fear could deepen divisions and invite even more chaos and legal battles. Instead, we should focus on tightening election integrity and improving civic education so people better understand why the system exists in the first place.

As someone who works hard on the road and still can’t vote here, I think the president should be chosen by a national popular vote so every person’s choice counts the same, no matter the state. The Electoral College makes it feel like only a few swing states really matter and the rest of the people, including many immigrants and working-class folks, get ignored. If we keep any version of it, it should at least be reformed so electoral votes are divided more fairly by how people actually vote, not winner-take-all.

As someone who deeply believes in equal opportunities and one person, one vote, I think we should move toward a national popular vote to replace the Electoral College. It doesn’t sit right with me that a candidate can win the presidency without winning the most votes, and it makes some states (like mine in Oklahoma) feel like they barely matter in presidential campaigns. A popular vote system would encourage candidates to speak to all Americans, not just swing-state voters, and better reflect the will of the people while still respecting our constitutional framework through a carefully designed reform or amendment.
